title.narrative: Save the Children activities in Syria and the region 2019

description.narrative: Save the Children activities in Syria and the region 2019

organisation.narrative: Humanitarian Action, Civil Society and Engagement

description.narrative: FL §06.39.03.11 Other contributions to acute and prolonged crises

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative:
2. Improved protective environment for vulnerable Syrian IDPs, refugee, returnees and host community children affected by grave child rights violations; harmful work and child marriage
2.1 Vulnerable conflict-affected children have increased resilience
2.2 Parents and caregivers are better able to support their children’s CP and psychosocial needs
2.3 The capacity of communities and local actors are strengthened to respond to CP and psychosocial needs of conflict affected children

# of conflict-affected girls and boys participating in PSS and Resilience activities (2,130 (SYR 1,000; LEB 450; JOR 680)) # of girls and boys assisted through case management and referrals complimented with Individual Protection Assistance (830 (SYR 400; LEB 230; JOR 200)) % of girls and boys showing improvement in resilience and wellbeing (70)
# of parents and caregivers participating in parenting programs (810 (JOR 360; LEB 450) % of parents and caregivers indicate feeling increased confidence in supporting their children (JOR 70; LEB 55) CP committees (CPCs) established, trained and active (7 (JOR 2; SYR 5)) % CPC members with increased knowledge in CP, PFA, Safe Identification and Referral,mobilization, rapid assessment, facilitation skills, advocacy, GBV indicators & gender equality, inclusion (JOR 70%, SYR 50%) # of partner staff trained on CP principles and the risks of harmful work and child marriage (32 (LEB 12; JOR 20)) # of individuals reached through awareness raising

Children and their families/caregivers recently displaced due to the escalation of conflict in NW Syria benefit from timely, safe, dignified and high-quality assistance to cover their basic physical and protection needs.
1.1 Recently displaced HHs are able to meet their immediate needs

Needs and market assessment prior to cash distribution Distribution lists PDM
# Multi-purpose cash grant distributed to vulnerable families # Ready to Eat Rations distributed to vulnerable families # NFI kits distributed to vulnerable families

3. Strengthen the protective environment of vulnerable, hard-to-reach and out-of-school children through improved and safe access to quality education pathways suitable to their needs
3.1 Barriers preventing vulnerable, hard-to-reach and out-of-school children from accessing education are addressed
3.2 Enrolled children benefit from a quality learning and participatory educational environment

# of vulnerable IDP, refugees and returnees with access to safe and inclusive learning (360 (LEB 160; JOR 200) # of HHs supported with cash assistance with an aim to improve their children’s protection and access to education (350 (LEB 150; JOR 200)
# teachers trained on basic literacy and Numeracy, child-centred pedagogy, classroom management methods, PSS (LEB 8) % of targeted girls and boys who demonstrate an improvement in literacy and numeracy levels (70)

1. Children and their families/caregivers recently displaced due to the escalation of conflict in NW Syria benefit from timely, safe, dignified and high-quality assistance to cover their basic physical and protection needs. 1.1 Recently displaced HHs are able to meet their immediate needs

2. Improved protective environment for vulnerable Syrian IDPs, refugee, returnees and host community children affected by grave child rights violations; harmful work and child marriage
2.1 Vulnerable conflict-affected children have increased resilience
2.2 Parents and caregivers are better able to support their children’s CP and psychosocial needs
2.3 The capacity of communities and local actors are strengthened to respond to CP and psychosocial needs of conflict affected children

# of conflict-affected girls and boys participating in PSS and Resilience activities (2,130 (SYR 1,000; LEB 450; JOR 680)) # of girls and boys assisted through case management and referrals complimented with Individual Protection Assistance (830 (SYR 400; LEB 230; JOR 200)) % of girls and boys showing improvement in resilience and wellbeing (70)
# of parents and caregivers participating in parenting programs (810 (JOR 360; LEB 450) % of parents and caregivers indicate feeling increased confidence in supporting their children (JOR 70; LEB 55) CP committees (CPCs) established, trained and active (7 (JOR 2; SYR 5)) % CPC members with increased knowledge in CP, PFA, Safe Identification and Referral,mobilization, rapid assessment, facilitation skills, advocacy, GBV indicators & gender equality, inclusion (JOR 70%, SYR 50%) # of partner staff trained on CP principles and the risks of harmful work and child marriage (32 (LEB 12; JOR 20)) # of individuals reached through awareness raising

3. Strengthen the protective environment of vulnerable, hard-to-reach and out-of-school children through improved and safe access to quality education pathways suitable to their needs
3.1 Barriers preventing vulnerable, hard-to-reach and out-of-school children from accessing education are addressed
3.2 Enrolled children benefit from a quality learning and participatory educational environment
